Award.AwardTitle: Practical Filtering Methods with Model Errors
Award.AbstractNarration:
The projects in this proposal are part of the PI's long-term career goal to deliver a class of practically scalable data assimilation (or filtering) schemes with solid theoretical foundations for state estimation of geophysical fluid dynamics. This proposal is an outgrowth of the PI's recent successful effort in designing accurate, reduced filtering methods with cheap stochastic models as alternatives to expensive models. Four projects are proposed: 1. Design computationally faster stochastic filters to assimilate atmospheric infrared sounder (AIRS) in the presence of multiple cloud types in the tropics. 2. Develop stable linear autoregressive (AR) filters for nonlinear, weakly chaotic dynamical systems. This project involves designing a novel parameterization scheme for AR models that avoids utilizing a long time series as in classical regression strategy, yet respects the sufficient conditions for optimal AR filtering, established in the PI's recent work. 3. Study the role of higher order terms of the singular perturbation expansion when a reduced model from classical averaging theory is used in filtering multi-scale interaction between modes of turbulent signals with moderate separation of scales. This study involves formal asymptotic expansion and rigorous error estimation. The PI will show that the higher order terms are important to avoid covariance underestimation in the presence of model errors. 4. Develop a fast filtering framework to assimilate multi-scale dynamical systems with "superparameterization", a fast numerical scheme to resolve interaction of cloud-scale dynamics and large-scale tropical convecting atmosphere. The new algorithm will include an online small-scale estimation scheme that imposes statistical consistency between the large and small-scale variables.

Fundamental issues in real-time weather prediction are model errors. This problem is attributed to incomplete understanding of the physics and our lack of computational resources to resolve physical processes in various time and length scales. Modern operational weather models poorly reproduce the tropical observational records even after resolving 10 billion variables. This long-standing issue prevents the global weather model forecasting skill to improve from weekly to monthly, as reported in a recent article in the World Meteorological Organization bulletin. The results from this proposal will transform the future design of computational methods for various prediction related problems in the presence of model errors, in particular numerical weather prediction. This proposal supports an interdisciplinary research training environment for a graduate student, involving mathematical analysis, statistical modeling, and scientific computing. The PI, who is jointly appointed as a faculty in the mathematics and meteorology departments at PSU, will develop an interdisciplinary graduate course with emphasis on PDE and waves for atmospheric and ocean modeling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data assimilation is a statistical method that uses the available observation to calibrate parameters or estimate the current state of a dynamical model, a mathematical model that can be used to predict the variables of interest at the future times. The main goal of the projects in this proposal is to deliver a class of practically scalable data assimilation schemes in the presence of model errors, which is the key issue in any scientific discipline that involves modeling.

The scientific results from this award include a fundamental understanding of model error in data assimilation, especially when the model error arises from incomplete understanding of the physical processes and our incapability to resolve the multiple scales physical processes with the current computing capability. This theory suggested that one way to mitigate model error in data assimilation is to use dynamical models that involve randomness, which technical term is known as stochastic dynamics.

The approaches developed during the course of this award can be classified into two groups, the parametric and nonparametric modeling.

A parametric modeling involves a particular choice of modeling (such as the stochastic model) based on some physical laws and then estimates the parameters in the proposed model from the given data. We have introduced several systematic strategies to deduce reduced-order stochastic dynamical models and several parameter estimation methods to calibrate the parameters of these stochastic models. In terms of data assimilation technique, we have developed computationally efficient methods to improve the statistical estimations in the presence of model errors. These methods have been implemented with success in the state estimation of monsoon-Hadley convective flows using the satellite observations. 

Another difficult problem that is addressed in this proposal is the data assimilation of satellite measurement under the cloudy-sky condition. The problem here, again, is modeling error, due to the difficulty in estimating the cloud fraction and cloud top high. We have introduced a new method that can be used to assimilate these satellite measurements (which are usually discarded in the state-of-art operational weather forecasting data assimilation systems).  

A nonparametric modeling does not assume any physical laws or any specific model of choices. Instead, it completely uses the available data to model the unknown dynamics. We have invented a novel equation-free modeling technique that solves the mathematical equations that model the physical processes without knowing the equations (or the underlying mechanism). Here, our method uses the data to construct the model as opposed to the standard parametric modeling approach where the data is used to estimate the parameters in the model. Under appropriate assumptions, we rigorously proved that this new nonparametric approach solves the underlying dynamical models.

As a third modeling paradigm, we also introduced a new semi-parametric modeling to account for missing dynamics in high-dimensional systems. Our approach compensates for model error by learning an auxiliary dynamical model for the unknown parameters that can change in time. The semi-parametric forecasting algorithm consists of integrating the existing physics-based model with an ensemble of parameters sampled from the distribution of the nonparametric model. To specify initial conditions for this modeling paradigm, a novel semi-parametric data assimilation method was introduced.

Through the projects in this award, the PI has mentored three undergraduate students, three graduate students, and two postdoctoral researchers. This award funded one of the undergraduate students in a summer research program and two graduate students as research assistants. The total number of papers includes two published book chapters, 14 published peer-reviewed articles, and one paper is under review. Beyond these formal publications, the PI has disseminated the results through various conference and seminar presentations.
